p: Armillaria species may act either as a primary pathogen frequently observed in disease centres causing gradual, multiyear reduction on the growth and yield of healthy trees, or as a secondary pathogen, infecting and killing already weakened trees [ 174]. When colonizing living hosts, rhizomorphs penetrate the root surface by combining mechanical pressure and enzymatic activities. Then the penetrating rhizomorphs form mycelial fans underneath the bark, induce tissue necrosis and decompose the underlying cambium, causing the decay of the secondary xylem [ 22].
